messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: This is pretty gold tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon et al, I read it somewhere that they sometimes lacquered the solid gold tsuba to  by pass  that law about not being too  in your face show off
messages.messageBody:
Gordon et al,
I read it somewhere that they sometimes lacquered the solid gold tsuba to "
by pass " that law about not being too " in your face show off " thingie.

milt

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: This is pretty gold tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Yeah, they are pretty neat. Gordon ... From: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@westnet.com.au] Sent: Thursday, November 13, 2003 3:43 PM To:
messages.messageBody:
Yeah, they are pretty neat.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Richard Turner [mailto:ikkanshi@...]
Sent: Thursday, November 13, 2003 3:43 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: This is pretty gold tsuba



amazing, it would be pretty cool to catalogue these, not that it would be a
big catalogue but photo's would be cool. When I come to Japan I will try and
hunt them down for a look.

cheers Gordon

Rich
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 13, 2003 11:16 AM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: This is pretty gold tsuba


Rich and Jim,



There was one other one out on display at Choshu-ya two weekends ago, also
Umetada and also with file marks and ko-sukashi. That now makes three that
I
have seen. There is also the dai-sho pair on Hideyoshi's dai-sho that are
go-san kiri-mono sukashi pieces. As Jim notes, the majority were melted
down, particularly when money got tight.



Gordon

messages.messageBody:
amazing, it would be pretty cool to catalogue these, not that it would be a big catalogue but photo's would be cool. When I come to Japan I will try and hunt them down for a look.

cheers Gordon

Rich
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, November 13, 2003 11:16 AM

Rich and Jim,



There was one other one out on display at Choshu-ya two weekends ago, also
Umetada and also with file marks and ko-sukashi. That now makes three that I
have seen. There is also the dai-sho pair on Hideyoshi's dai-sho that are
go-san kiri-mono sukashi pieces. As Jim notes, the majority were melted
down, particularly when money got tight.



Gordon

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: This is pretty gold tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich and Jim, There was one other one out on display at Choshu-ya two weekends ago, also Umetada and also with file marks and ko-sukashi. That now makes three
messages.messageBody:
Rich and Jim,



There was one other one out on display at Choshu-ya two weekends ago, also
Umetada and also with file marks and ko-sukashi. That now makes three that I
have seen. There is also the dai-sho pair on Hideyoshi's dai-sho that are
go-san kiri-mono sukashi pieces. As Jim notes, the majority were melted
down, particularly when money got tight.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Thursday, November 13, 2003 9:41 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: This is pretty gold tsuba



Rich,
I think that the one from the Compton koshirae was Ko-Kinko or maybe early
Edo period. It was gold "plate" as you say.

Solid gold tsuba are pretty rare today. The same owner has another one,
also Umetada and both from around the Momoyama period. I doubt that they
were ever common, but probably most examples were melted down once they were
no longer in use. The Umetada ones are finished with very controlled file
marks like the ones seen on their habaki of the period.
Jim



cool, thanks Jim. How many tsuba would have been solid gold ?. I am not
going to remember the smith but there is a lovely gold foiled/sheet ? plated
tsuba ( I think ) in Comptons 100 famous swords. Part of a complete set of
koshirae I believe. It features paulownia flowers over waves from memory.


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: This is pretty gold tsuba
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, I think that the one from the Compton koshirae was Ko-Kinko or maybe early Edo period.  It was gold plate as you say. Solid gold tsuba are pretty rare
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
I think that the one from the Compton koshirae was Ko-Kinko or maybe early Edo period. It was gold "plate" as you say.

Solid gold tsuba are pretty rare today. The same owner has another one, also Umetada and both from around the Momoyama period. I doubt that they were ever common, but probably most examples were melted down once they were no longer in use. The Umetada ones are finished with very controlled file marks like the ones seen on their habaki of the period.
Jim



cool, thanks Jim. How many tsuba would have been solid gold ?. I am not going to remember the smith but there is a lovely gold foiled/sheet ? plated tsuba ( I think ) in Comptons 100 famous swords. Part of a complete set of koshirae I believe. It features paulownia flowers over waves from memory.
